column4: anyone here know  of a linux publishing program?  (ability to import .pub files would be good too)
scribus. don't think it imports from .pub
i don't think you'll find *many* alternatives, though you'll probably find one or two. what about just using a word processor? those things can do a lot of layouting nowadays
you can still isntall KWord if you like, you'll just get a few libraries with it (sudo aptitude install kword will allow you to remove them easily later)
scribus itself is a Qt/KDE program, so it'll have installed some of those already
I here you need to install another library to make qt not look gross.  Do you know which one it is? (its kde related)
wouldn't really know.. i'm using KDE, so that's the kind of problem I can have with *Gnome* programs ;-)
but i think Dapper, by default, uses a reasonable enough theme for KDE inside Gnome... at least I think it did for me when I last tried
perhaps you could install qt3-qtconfig, that will allow you to select from a (limited) set of (not-very-good) themes
i like it better as a concept -- it's less bloated, both from a performance and a GUI-cluttering point of view... however, it crashes
i try to use koffice whenever i can, but i end up having openoffice installed too most of the time
if its faster, and compatible with the ms documents we are fed, it should be nice since this is a low end system
it's certainly faster to load... i think it's also faster during operation
for a low end system, you could also give AbiWord a try. it's surely more stable than KWord, though it's probably the one with the smallest feature set (but good enough for many purposes)

on the other hand, i'm not sure kword is a good choice for a low end system that's running *Gnome*. it'll mean loading up the KDE libraries *as well* as the gnome libraries, which will probably make startup time go up, and keep more RAM filled

kde doesn't crash *too* much in my experience, although koffice itself certainly does. konqueror crashes a bit too much these times (at least here), but it's very fast to recover with the "Crash" plug-in, if nothing else
i dunno about that, scribus is *intended* for layouting, while kword is intended as a word processor -- though it's actually much more layout-oriented that openoffice writer
scribus certainly looked kind of ugly/unintuitive when i tried it
